Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Polarization Sensitive Multi-Chroic MKIDs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative project to build a system of arrays that will serve as a pathfinder for future Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) instruments. The arrays will use detectors known as Microwave Kinetic Inductance Device (MKID) detectors in multiple frequencies between 130 GHz and 280 GHz. Each array will have 20 elements. Broader impacts of the work include the training of undergraduate and graduate students in instrumentation development, which helps build the US workforce in STEM fields.

The MKID arrays are tailored for experiments that are designed to simultaneously characterize the polarization properties of both the cosmic microwave background (CMB) and Galactic dust emission. The device design builds from successful transition edge sensor (TES) bolometer architectures that have been demonstrated to work in instruments on the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) and South Pole Telescope (SPT).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaboration between scientists at Columbia University, Stanford University, the University of Michigan and Arizona State University to design and build a new type of sensor to revolutionize our ability to map detailed properties of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) radiation - the light left over from the very early universe.

The CMB is light that was generated in the young universe when the density and temperature were many orders of magnitude higher than today. As the universe has expanded, this radiation has remained but its energy has decreased as the wavelength of each CMB photon has been stretched by the expansion. Now, the CMB still fills the universe but is invisible to the human eye and requires sensitive detectors that are able to "see" light at much longer wavelengths. For comparison, the wavelength of light that we see as the color red is approximately 600 nanometers, while the peak wavelength of the CMB today is approximately 1 mm or over 1000x more red.

There have been a number of sensors used to make measurements of the CMB. For example the PLANCK satellite that made the best map so far of the CMB over the entire sky used a combination of bolometers, which are thermal sensors, and radio transistor amplifiers. All of these sensors were cooled to temperatures close to absolute zero (0 degrees Kelvin) to maximize their sensitivity to the CMB which appears as a thermal source with an effective temperature of 2.75 K. A higher signal to noise ratio CMB map than PLANCK is needed to find evidence for even fainter features from the early universe, in particular to detect variations in the polarization of the CMB that were left over from primordial gravitational waves.

The PLANCK satellite had on order of 100 separate channels each of which is like an independent pixel measuring a different wavelength or color on the sky. In comparison, an optical camera in a cell phone typically has 10s or 100s of millions of pixels. More pixels would enable an image with higher signal to noise so the next generation of CMB experiments are all aiming to have cameras with 10s of thousands of pixels instead of 100s of pixels. However, there are many technical challenges to making a large array of pixels that have to work at extremely low temperatures including getting the signals that are detected by the pixels out to a room temperature system that can produce images and store the data for later analysis.

One new technology that is specifically designed to enable large arrays of sensitive detectors is the Kinetic Inductance Detector (KID). A KID is a superconducting resonator that changes its resonant frequency (like the tone of a tuning fork) when different amounts of light are shined on it. An array of resonators, each with a different frequency can be connected to a single readout line and all read out in parallel using a technique called frequency division multiplexing. In this project, we designed an array of KID pixels where each pixel is capable of measuring at least two colors and two polarizations of light from the CMB and the data from the entire array can be sent to a room temperature computer with only two small cables. This technology would enable future CMB experiments to increase the number of pixels by several orders of magnitude. A picture of the pixel design is shown in the attached figure.
